chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The solemnity of the sealed book with seven seals, its acceptance, and the vision of its revelation are recalled. The inspection of the white horse is narrated with the opening of the first seal. The red horse with the second seal, and the black horse with the third seal, are mentioned. The pale horse with the fourth seal. With the fifth seal, the souls of the martyrs are found under the altar of God. An earthquake, the darkening of the sun, the moon turning to blood, and the falling stars. Four angels are described as holding the four corners of the earth. The number of those marked from each tribe is mentioned. An innumerable multitude from all nations is foretold. The Lamb in the midst of the throne will rule them.

The law of God can be understood in three ways, or even more, but it must be known through correct exposition, as taught by the testimonies themselves. As we read in Solomon (Proverbs 7): "Write them on the tablet of your heart;" similarly, remember it is written in the book of Job (Chapter 11): "Oh, that God would speak with you and show you the secrets of wisdom, which are manifold!" But because things approved by the same spirit cannot contradict each other, it is easily demonstrated by sound reasoning that both are consistent. It is of utmost importance to apply interpretations to the sacred scriptures that do not deviate from the truth of those texts. Instead, by soberly understanding the author's intent, they should be elucidated beneficially and should always correspond with the rules of faith and truth. For it should not be considered contradictory that when the Spirit of God is described as unique or simple (Wisdom 7), it is also immediately described as manifold or varied, as the diversity of translations shows. It is certainly simple in the singular nature of its property, yet manifold in the distributions of grace; or it is celebrated in three ways for the remission of sins: by baptism, penance, and martyrdom, as the psalmist sings (Psalms).

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered. Blessed is the man to whom the Lord does not impute sin. It is believed that sins are forgiven through baptism, covered through penance, and not imputed through martyrdom.

However, other Fathers said that sins are forgiven in seven ways, adding almsgiving to the acquisition of debt remission, restraining a neighbor from error, and the abundance of charity, through which we read that the abundance of sins is covered. Proverbs chapter ten.

These seven ways can also be comprehended within those three ways, which are more clearly expounded. The reason for this preface will soon be explained in the following reading.

As we hasten to explain difficult passages, we do not want to be marked by rash advancement or judged by anyone as forgetful of paternal tradition.
chunks.original_latin:
XXXI): Beati quorum remissae sunt
iniquitates, et quorum tecta sunt peccata; beatus vir
cui non imputavit Dominus peccatum, ut baptismo
remitti, poenitentia tegi, martyrio non imputari
credantur. Alii tamen Patres septem modis dixerunt
relaxari, addentes eleemosynas debitae remissionis
acquisitioni, proximi ab errore cohibiti, et
abundantiam charitatis, per quam cooperiri abundantiam
legimus peccatorum (Prov X). Possunt autem
intra illos tres modos isti quoque comprehensi
manere, qui latius clareant expediti. Quorsum ista
praemiserim, sequentis mox lectionis docebit excursus;
exponendis namque locis arduis properantes
nolumus aut temeritatis progressu notari, aut paternae
traditionis obliviosi ab aliquo judicari.
